At-a-Glance: Trap sparingly, dry quickly, and store cold and dark. Colony nutrition comes first.
Why it Matters: Prevents brood setbacks and hygienic stress.
Objectives: Use traps only during strong pollen flows.
Cleanly collect and rapidly chill or dry.
What Good Looks Like: Traps fitted level and cleaned daily; doors open on off-days.
Pellets collected into clean containers; chilled within hours.
Batch codes with apiary/date; moisture validated.
Step-by-Step: 1) Confirm strong pollen flow and colony strength; fit trap.
2) Collect daily; remove debris; avoid crushing.
3) Dry ≤40 °C to target moisture or freeze; store opaque/airtight.
4) Rest colonies; remove trap during dearth.
Seasonality & Climate: Spring flows best; avoid late-season stress.
Humidity demands faster drying and sealed storage.
Data & Thresholds: Rest ratio (e.g., 2 on / 5 off days) to protect brood.
Diagnostics & Decision Tree: Symptom: Brood thinning -> Reduce trapping; feed substitute if needed.
Symptom: Off odour -> Discard; improve speed and drying.
Symptom: Mites in trays -> Improve cleaning and freeze pre-pack.
Tools & Techniques: Underfloor/entrance traps, sieves, dehydrator, moisture meter.
Safety & Compliance: Food hygiene and allergen labelling for pollen.
Communications: Explain seasonality and ethical limits to customers.
Notes: Sieve out hive debris before drying to improve quality and appearance.
